author: tlmii
body:
In the dashboard we have a few cases where we need to generate CSS directly from C# code. We do this both in .razor files and .razor.cs files and using both ToString() and string interpolation. All of those scenarios by default use the current culture. But in CSS it need to be invariant culture (specifically to prevent commas being used instead of decimal point as seen in #841).

We already have CA1305 enabled as a warning for .cs files. 

First, we should look at whether this can be enabled for .razor files as well to force us to think about it when using it in .razor files.

Second, we should look at what we can do about string interpolation. I don't think that analyzer does anything for string interpolation (could be wrong) in .cs or .razor files. But this is increasingly what we're using as opposed to the calls caught by CA1305. So we need some way to ensure we're consistent about it and avoid similar, hard to track down bugs.

nodes.author: tlmii
nodes.body: This appears to be the relevant issue for string interpolation analyzers: https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn-analyzers/issues/2150

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: @tlmii - any reason to keep this one open any longer? Can we close or, is this still a thing?

title: Analyzers/Warnings for consistent non-localized CSS string generation

author: DamianEdwards
body:
The `ServiceDefaults` project today provides methods that are called from service projects to configure common defaults like metrics, HTTP client service discovery, health checks, etc. For some common concerns though, using the configuration system, e.g. JSON files, is the preferred.

We should enable the `ServiceDefaults` project to contribute to the configuration of the projects that reference it. This would be done in the following way:

- Have *appsettings-shared.json* and *appsettings-shared.Development.json* files in the `ServiceDefaults` project that shared configuration can be set in. Note the filename scheme here is specifically crafted to ensure compatibility with the existing scheme used in the default JSON configuration file sources added to most apps today, i.e. `appsettings[.{EnvironmentName}.].json`. Using '.' to separate the `shared` suffix would lead to ambiguity (is "shared" an environment name or sentinel for shared config?). Alternatively we could use a scheme like `shared.appsettings[.{EnvironmentName}.].json`
- A new package (e.g. *Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Json.Shared*) that would be referenced by the `ServiceDefaults` project that contains:
  - APIs to add the shared configuration sources to an app's configuration builder. The sources should be added **before** the app's own *appsettings.json* files to ensure that shared config does not override app-local config.
  - MSBuild targets that include the shared appsettings JSON files in the build output of the `ServiceDefaults` project (i.e. the project directly referencing the NuGet package)
  - MSBuild targets that flow transitively to projects that reference the `ServiceDefaults` project, that facilitate flowing details about the shared configuration JSON files to the app assemblies during inner-loop, such that the shared JSON files can be loaded directly from the `ServiceDefaults` project at runtime (rather than relying on file copying) and thus supporting editing of these files and having those changes reflected in real-time when running from Visual Studio, etc. (this is very similar to how StaticWebAssets works today in ASP.NET Core projects)

A partial implementation of this proposal can be seen in [here](https://github.com/DamianEdwards/eShopLite/tree/sharedconfig). It doesn't use the MSBuild targets proposed (like StaticWebAssets) but rather facilitates the coordination from data injected by the DevHost project, but the other aspects are inline with what's proposed here.

nodes.author: danmoseley
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards  is this still relevant? for 8.0

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: We can move post-GA to reassess then.

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards - still any interest in this one?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @bradygaster possibly, but I haven't found myself wanting it for a while. I'd be more interested in getting the dynamic JSON schema stuff moved from VS into the .NET SDK.

title: Enable the ServiceDefaults project to contribute shared configuration to projects that reference it

author: asimmon
body:
I'm really glad that Preview 2 of Aspire added the `AddProject` overload so we can reference a .NET project by providing an arbitrary project path. However, I feel like Aspire currently assumes that this project is part of (and referenced by) the app host solution, which would result in the project being built before being orchestrated by Aspire. If my project is not part of the app host solution and it has not been compiled yet, Aspire will fail to run it as it uses `--no-build` when preparing the projects.

In my opinion, this process somewhat defeats the purpose of using `AddProject` with a custom path because if my project is already part of my solution, I would simply use `AddProject<>` with the generated service metadata.

Is there any plan to consider building the .NET project prior to running it when using `AddProject` with a custom path? I believe this overload would be beneficial for scenarios where developers deal with multiple solutions in a monorepo (or even multiple repos).

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Yes I think we should enable this. But you also want debugging inside of the IDE as well right?

nodes.author: asimmon
nodes.body:
Yes, that would be great, although I'm not sure about the specifics of the experience. For now, building the project before running it would be enough.

When thinking about the debugging experience in .NET Aspire, I consider the possibility of instructing my app host code to attach the debugger to a specific resource right at its startup. On another note, I also think about a way to interact with the dashboard to manually attach to a process as needed. For now, I can already copy the process ID and manually attach to it from the IDE.

I remember that [Tye uses a host startup hook](https://github.com/dotnet/tye/blob/release/0.11.0/src/Microsoft.Tye.Hosting.Runtime/StartupHook.cs) to attach the debugger to the process at startup. But that's only valid for .NET apps.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Following up with some conversations the team has had about this topic. The solution we propose is building the project from the app host if it isn't part of the solution and adding support for attaching to arbitrary processes within VS. We think that combination of fixes will address this gap.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
> The solution we propose is building the project from the app host if it isn't part of the solution

Curious, how do we know that? Are we just assuming if the project is added via a .csproj path then it's not part of the solution and will try to build it, or do we have a more concrete signal? I'm concerned what will happen if we try to kick off a build of a project that's already being managed by VS.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: I think that’s what we’d do. If it’s not added as a reference to the apphost then we build it. Not sure what else we can glean.

nodes.author: ChristophHornung
nodes.body:
I really wanted to use Aspire in our multi-repo environment so I added the ability to add external projects (just using dotnet run here) and made sure to wire up the same parts that `AddProject` does.

So if anybody wants to check this out before Aspire has official support for the scenario try the [nuget](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Chorn.Aspire.ExternalProject/1.0.0).

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
This is very cool @ChristophHornung !! We’ve discussed making this work in a similar way but changing the dcp protocol to make attach debugger work.

A few pieces of feedback (things we worried about using this technique):
- I see you’re using dotnet run, that’ll work well until you start running concurrently on projects in the same solution. AFAIK it’ll end up being uncoordinated and potentially may lead to conflicts/problems 
- The way you get the pid is problematic and will break in 9.1 (we redecorated all of this code so your private reflection will break) https://github.com/ChristophHornung/Aspire.ExternalProject/blob/9fd75e1d3e27ce878bbedec6d6d8dd0149471739/Chorn.Aspire.ExternalProject/ExternalProjectBuilderExtensions.cs#L147

For the first problem, one possible solution is to build up a single project file (msbuild file that references other projects) on the fly to compile multiple projects that may come from the same solution file and build that before starting the executable.

The season one you would use the resource notification service to get the pid instead of using private reflection. It should be available in a well know property (it shows in the dashboard)


PS: This is very impressive work! I’m happy you were able to build and figure out this without changing the core. We have some things we need to expose to make publish work well but I think it would be possible to do it in your repo as well.

nodes.author: ChristophHornung
nodes.body:
@davidfowl Whoaw, thanks for the quick feedback.

On the topic of concurrent `dotnet run`s. I am not too versed on how the build works internally. I tried using the -o flag bug noticed that even when using `dotnet build -o ...` the obj folder was still created on referenced projects so I assumed it would not make much of a difference and just used `dotnet run`. I like the idea of stopping, git pull and starting again, this might be tricky when wrapping projects into a solution. I think I have to test that scenario a bit more.

Getting the pid is admittedly quick and dirty, and I saw that classes were renamed in the main branch. I did not see another way on first glance but will check out the resource notification service. Many thanks for pointing me in the right direction.

Could you elaborate on what you mean with `changing the dcp protocol to make attach debugger work`? This is the one area where I am really unhappy at the moment as the `vsjitdebugger -p <pid>` does not work correctly on any of my machines. (I can select my VS2022 instance but no breakpoints are hit). So I always have to manually attach from my VS instance searching through the list of processes.

nodes.author: asimmon
nodes.body:
We built similar custom dotnet resource orchestration for external projects, to allow us going multi-repo. The main build concurrency issue we faced was when two or more dotnet processes tried to access a particular file for writing (like, a DLL). Our workaround so far was to use dotnet watch, build a custom lifecyclehook watching for build errors (`CS2012` for instance), and... bump the project file timestamp to force dotnet watch rebuild the project. It feels hacky, startup time may be increased, but it works.

We might explore the idea of generating a single parent csproj file at runtime to prevent this if this becomes too annoying for the devs.

nodes.author: Odessa-ShubhanChemburkar
nodes.body:
> What problem are you hoping to solve with multitargeting here?

@lewing Here is the scenario for me

Aspire allows to add .NET project using `builder.AddProject`, the project being added could have multi targeting like 
```xml
<PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFrameworks>net48;net8.0;net9.0</TargetFrameworks>
</PropertyGroup>
```

For such a project when running manually via command line the `--framework` option is required
e.g.

`dotnet run SomeProject.csproj --framework net8.0`

Currently it is not possible to add the `--framework` argument using any `builder.AddProject` overloads.

<ProjectReference Include="..\..\MultiTargetted\Project.csproj" SetTargetFramework="TargetFramework=net9.0" />

Then running and testing from Visual Studio works fine, but when I run or test from the commandline using dotnet run or dotnet test, I still get this same error:

    Your project targets multiple frameworks. Specify which framework to run using '--framework'.

nodes.author: timheuer
nodes.body:
@NicoVermeir @ciaranodonnell Right now this is how the Wasm debugging works. Since it uses JavaScript debugging there needs to be a defined process to attach to and one that is also configured for remote debugging (`--remote-debugging`) (which likely any default browser instance isn't).  So when we have a Blazor Wasm project we launch an instance of the browser with these settings and the debugger can attach to.

You can disable the auto launch by modifying the `launchSettings.json` in the Wasm project and setting `launchBrowser:false` there -- but then you won't get the Wasm debugging experience...maybe a mitigation to use and turn it on when you want to debug Wasm as well.

The reason I think its a challenging developer experience is that I have 3 blazor wasm projects in my solution that all have that `launchBrowser:true` and it only launches it for one of the projects. The newest one. The others have been in there for months and other than a period a few weeks ago where it did this for an afternoon, they've never had the second browser launch. I was having to launch my own debug browser and debug the C# in the chrome dev tools (Which was a terrible experience of its own). 
I want the WASM debugging, but I want it to actually launch the browser successfully, and if it cant I don't want it to model over my VS and then tear it all down when I dismiss the error.

title: Blazor Aspire MS Identity combination

author: SteveSandersonMS
body:
There's some difference in how VS launches Aspire projects launch compared with how it launches regular ASP.NET Core projects, e.g., Blazor Web ones.

With a default Blazor project, and assuming you have hot reload enabled, each time you ctrl+f5, VS will reuse the same browser tab if you have one open. With Aspire, each time you ctrl+f5 it opens a new tab for the dashboard, which leads to continually closing duplicate tabs.

Or is this just on my machine?

nodes.author: ahazelwood
nodes.body: This issue, plus the lack of browserlink to hot reload changes is slowing down development considerably.

author: afscrome
body:
After upgrading a Preview 6 project to Preview 7, the upgrade assistant added `Version` attributes into my application's csproj file rather than upgrading the versions in `Directory.Packages.props`

```
Severity    Code    Description    Project    File    Line    Suppression State
Error (active)    NU1008    Projects that use central package version management should not define the version on the PackageReference items but on the PackageVersion items: Aspire.Microsoft.Data.SqlClient;Aspire.Hosting.RabbitMQ;Aspire.Hosting.Redis;Aspire.Hosting.AppHost;Microsoft.Extensions.Diagnostics.HealthChecks;Aspire.Hosting.SqlServer;Aspire.RabbitMQ.Client.    MYAPP.APPHOST    C:\...\MYAPPAPPHOST.csproj    1  
```

I'd have expected the upgrade process to not break the `PackageReferences` in the app host's csproj.

Note from @davidfowl on discord:
> That's not really an upgrade assistant bug
and unfortunate side effect of nothngi working with CPM 😄
but feel free to file it on github

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: @JakeRadMSFT and @vijayrkn - it sounds like from the Discord comment in the issue that this isn't specific to UA. I reached out to @abpiskunov to validate if it's UA-specific

title: [WebToolsE2E][Aspire] On non-ENU OS, the description of the Aspire SDK component in the VS installer is not localized.

author: maddymontaquila
body:
cc @BretJohnson @bradygaster 

It would be great to launch .NET MAUI apps from the AppHost file, see them on the dashboard, and auto-hook-up all the endpoints and such. This *sort-of* works but I would like to formalize it and make sure it works well and aligned with how aspire actually does its thing

**Requirements**
* Can add/reference .NET MAUI app in the AppHost file
* Ability to choose which MAUI target to launch: via apphost? something in VS or VSCode tooling? Something in the dashboard perhaps would be cool - "Start MAUI app" > popup to choose device???
* Endpoint configuration - ie, the Android emulator/iOS sim/device/local Windows or mac app should use some form of devtunnel etc to talk to the APIs and other containers spun up
* Support for OTEL? I have no idea if this would "just work" or not
* NON GOAL - deployment is unnecessary unless Aspire gets a really great CI/CD story down the line. Mobile apps aren't really... deployed lol. But they use plenty of deployed things!

Bret had taken a stab at a proof of concept of this here https://github.com/BretJohnson/aspire-mobile - I think we need to change how we're doing launch in this though (currently, you ctrl+f5 the app host then start the maui app separately... ideally we do something better than that!)

For reference, this is how you currently choose a debug target/TFM (maui uses multi-targeting) in VS and VS Code when you debug a MAUI app. you often change between different targets, so we need a way for people to do this in aspire. 

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/assets/12660687/2cee4c1b-4daa-4d41-bcc7-3cc21120d11b

(I cant get the vs code vid to upload ill add it later lol)

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body: Could possibly be related to https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/813

nodes.author: BretJohnson
nodes.body:
Thanks @maddymontaquila , for adding this. In terms of the launch experience, the two main options we've been discussing are:
1. Add new UI when launching from AppHost allowing the user to pick the target platform and device.
2. For MAUI apps, allow the MAUI app itself to be the startup project and have it implicitly launch the Aspire AppHost when launched, to startup the backend services (likely non-debug by default, but could be configurable). With this option, the current MAUI UI to choose target platform and device would continue to be used.

As for which option is better, we should continue to discuss, with an eye toward what most of our customers would prefer.
I've personally been liking option (2), as it's less of a change to existing user workflow & could potentially work for other scenarios too, like starting a non-Aspire ASP.NET backend automatically, but (1) is more of the current Aspire model.  In any case, I'm keen to hear what others, like @bradygaster and @sayedihashimi, think here.

nodes.author: BretJohnson
nodes.body: FYI - MAUI work to support Aspire is being tracked here: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/2000198/. But let's use this issue to track the Aspire support that's needed as part of that.

Yes, potentially. FYI, when we discussed this back in January @DamianEdwards said there are other scenarios, beyond MAUI, where they'd like to show some kind of launch UI in the future. I asked for examples and he said this:

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body:
> To give my input on the possible options mentioned in [#4684 (comment)](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/4684#issuecomment-2192668061)
> 
> While I would probably prefer option 2 initially because it fits more with the expected workflow of a .NET MAUI app developer I think option 1 would likely be a better fit as it gives a consistent approach to the current Aspire model as you said @BretJohnson


I'm with you here Shaun. I think 1 is the "right" thing to do from the Aspire perspective. Maybe we call that the MVP and listen to see if that really confuses people or it works okay. I don't think we'd need to separate out by TFM either - just a list of available debug targets we find.

nodes.author: BretJohnson
nodes.body:
> > To give my input on the possible options mentioned in [#4684 (comment)](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/4684#issuecomment-2192668061)
> > While I would probably prefer option 2 initially because it fits more with the expected workflow of a .NET MAUI app developer I think option 1 would likely be a better fit as it gives a consistent approach to the current Aspire model as you said @BretJohnson
> 
> I'm with you here Shaun. I think 1 is the "right" thing to do from the Aspire perspective. Maybe we call that the MVP and listen to see if that really confuses people or it works okay. I don't think we'd need to separate out by TFM either - just a list of available debug targets we find.

Though worth noting - I think that 1 is the more expensive option technically.

nodes.author: bijington
nodes.body: @BretJohnson When you say it is more expensive (not that I am footing the bill) but do you have any thoughts on how much more expensive over option 2? Could there be an option that starts with option 2 (or possibly a new option) but puts infrastructure in place for option 1?

nodes.author: BretJohnson
nodes.body:
@bijington - In terms of cost, we still need to design (design both UX and implementation) and cost it. And I think we should design and cost. I believe that @bradygaster will be looking at the experience design. Dev cost wise, I'd say probably at least a couple man months, but I'm just swaging and we need to dig in - which we should.

My main concern here is just to make sure we have a good sense of what customers (like yourself) actually want to do - what workflows want to support well. And use that knowledge to drive the spec / priorities. It'd be a shame to devote a lot of effort to supporting option 1, and only option 1, if option 2 is what folks actually would prefer most often in practice. Or maybe we should support both. For instance, most of the time when debugging the MAUI app would you also want to debug all the services? Most of the time when restarting the MAUI app would you want to restart all the services? That's clearly a useful option to support - which is a natural the Aspire model today. But do typical MAUI / client app devs want it to be the default - or only - option?

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body:
Ok so the current POC - 
- Everything is driven via the AppHost. You start debugging the apphost, and that will start the MAUI app along with all the other things. **Let's cost what it'll be for that to happen** if we use the launch UI @DamianEdwards had shared earlier to select a target device. (Also we can do something in that popout menu that says - to manage MAUI devices change your startup proj)
- Reference the MAUI proj in AppHost either with AddMauiApp or AddClientApp/AddNativeApp - leaning towards AddMauiApp so we don't accidentally pigeonhole ourselves into having supporting everything else right away
- Something something devtunnels @sayedihashimi is going to sort out LOL (related to #813 )
- The apphost/DCP should probably try to start the maui app ABSOLUTELY LAST so that it doesnt slow down the other builds - maui usually takes the longest. Maybe implicitly we use something like WaitOn() (or whatever we do for #921 ) when that gets implemented but user could override
- this will be icky until we implement something to help w #3095 since youll have to restart everything including the maui app every time and as we all know mobile b slow

cc @bradygaster @BretJohnson

author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

It would be useful to be able to configure a .NET project that you don't want the debugger attached when the app host is run with debugger.

I have a niche scenario where I explicitly don't want the debugger because the library has different behavior depending on whether the debugger is attached or not.

A more common ask for this is you don't want to debug into a particular app or be alerted by exceptions thrown in the app. There would also be performance benefits to not attaching the debugger to apps when not wanted.

### Describe the solution you'd like

An API in the app host to configure a .NET project not to be launched with the debugger attached.

### Additional context

_No response_
title: AppHost configuration to not attach debugger to a project

author: Brimerland
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

For ASP.Net Core apps a new browser window is started if "launchBrowser: true" is set in launchsettings.json. 
However, for Aspire this is different: With Firefox, instead of opening a new window, a new tab is

 opened in an already active Firefox browser (if present).

This behavior seems to confuse the tooling as it doesn't know which process to monitor to determine when to end the debugging session. The tooling waits for a new Firefox process to watch, leading to the following issues:

a) The debugging session does not close when the existing Firefox process exits.
b) The debugging session closes when the next Firefox process exists which was spawned after starting the Aspire App.
c) The next Firefox process spawned after starting the Aspire App is closed if the debugging session is stopped, **which may result in data loss**.

See attached video
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5d16095c-0e2b-4fa6-b049-4768891c9b7b

### Expected Behavior

A new Firefox window should be opened, and the correct process should be monitored to ensure proper debugging session management.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Set "launchBrowser" to true in launchsettings.json.
2. Open a Firefox browser.
3. Start debugging the Aspire App with Firefox as the default browser.
4. Notice that a new tab is opened instead of a new window.
5. Observe the described issues when the debugging session is stopped.

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

author: SteveSandersonMS
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

I'm running https://github.com/dotnet/eShopSupport from VS, launching using Ctrl+F5. I understand that when subsequently building a referenced project (e.g., the `Backend` project in that solution), VS is supposed to shut down and restart that one project while leaving AppHost running ([citation](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/1940)).

However, the vast majority of the time, this does not work for me, and building a referenced project fails with errors like:

```
1>C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\IntPreview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\amd64\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(5321,5): warning MSB3026: Could not copy "D:\git\dotnet\eShopSupport\src\Backend\obj\Debug\net8.0\apphost.exe" to "bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe". Beginning retry 1 in 1000ms. The process cannot access the file 'bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe' because it is being used by another process. The file is locked by: "Backend (2592)"
1>C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\IntPreview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\amd64\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(5321,5): warning MSB3026: Could not copy "D:\git\dotnet\eShopSupport\src\Backend\obj\Debug\net8.0\apphost.exe" to "bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe". Beginning retry 2 in 1000ms. The process cannot access the file 'bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe' because it is being used by another process. The file is locked by: "Backend (2592)"
1>C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\IntPreview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\amd64\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(5321,5): warning MSB3026: Could not copy "D:\git\dotnet\eShopSupport\src\Backend\obj\Debug\net8.0\apphost.exe" to "bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe". Beginning retry 3 in 1000ms. The process cannot access the file 'bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe' because it is being used by another process. The file is locked by: "Backend (2592)"
1>C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\IntPreview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\amd64\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(5321,5): warning MSB3026: Could not copy "D:\git\dotnet\eShopSupport\src\Backend\obj\Debug\net8.0\apphost.exe" to "bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe". Beginning retry 4 in 1000ms. The process cannot access the file 'bin\Debug\net8.0\Backend.exe' because it is being used by another process. The file is locked by: "Backend (2592)"
etc.
```

I've tried VS versions:

 * Version 17.11.0 Preview 4.0
 * Version 17.12.0 Preview 1.0 [35117.301.main]

and have disabled every VS extension I can, and disabled hot reload, but the same issue remains.

This is the most impactful issue on productivity when working on this project, as there's no choice but to manually kill and restart `AppHost` for literally every code change, which in turn means restarting some large Docker containers including Ollama.

I don't think it's specifically a problem in the app code, because it *sometimes* works. If I restart VS often enough and keep deleting the `.vs` directory, then occasionally it can rebuild the referenced projects without the file being locked. But this is a short-lived victory as the locking problem soon comes back and is present the vast majority of the time.

### Expected Behavior

VS should be able to rebuild referenced projects without failing due to the `.exe` or `.dll` files being locked.

### Steps To Reproduce

* Clone and run https://github.com/dotnet/eShopSupport (via Ctrl+F5 in VS)
* Visit `StaffWebUI` and observe it working
* Make any edit (e.g., whitespace) in `src/Backend/Program.cs` and try to build that one project
* Expected: builds that one project while leaving AppHost running
* Actual: fails with the "file locked" error mentioned above

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @vijayrkn I put this in 9.0. We should look at it.

nodes.author: BillHiebert
nodes.body: @davidfowl , @SteveSandersonMS so far I have not been able to reproduce this.  When looking more closely at the code I discovered that VS is not handling replicas properly. It was only stopping and restarting the first one. I have a PR out with a fix for that, but this project does not use replicas so something else must be going on.  From the VS side the code is very straight forward and it is difficult to see a case where it would not stop the process - unless the call to stop the process failed.

nodes.author: SteveSandersonMS
nodes.body: This bug occurred several times during my .NET@MS presentation yesterday - check the recording if you'd like to see! (Not sure when/where that becomes available). I was forced to restart the app completely a few times, which takes quite a while and certainly interfered with demo flow. This was on Aspire 9.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: How did you trigger the rebuild in VS?

nodes.author: SteveSandersonMS
nodes.body: Just pressing ctrl+b

nodes.author: Sjark
nodes.body:
This also happens when using dotnet run to run the app host.

I start the apphost using: `dotnet run  --project $appHostProjectPath --launch-profile http`

If I then try to build a spesific project, it fails with `The process cannot access the file '<filepath>' because it is being used by another process`

Workaround for now it to go to the aspire dashboard, stop the spesific service, do a build and start it again.

I have also tried the `no-build` flag on dotnet run, but still the same issue

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: When you use dotnet run it's expected. When you use visual studio or vs code now and rebuild a specific project, it will restart that project without intervention.

nodes.author: Sjark
nodes.body:
Just tested by running in VS Code, and it worked as expected when rebuilding a spesific project.

Is there any plans to supporting this when running using dotnet run or multiple vs code instances?

Our aspire project consist of multiple git repos/dotnet solutions. We have one "aspire" solution that has references to all the other .net projects, but we normally just open the one service we are going to work on in it's own vs code window.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> Is there any plans to supporting this when running using dotnet run

aspire run and dotnet watch

> or multiple vs code instances?

Not sure what you mean here

nodes.author: Sjark
nodes.body: Ok, I'll try aspire run. What I mean with multiple vs code instances is that we open each service/git repo in it's own vs code window, so I have one window VS Code window that has the Aspire App Host project, and a separate VS Code window that has the code for one of the services running in Aspire, so even if I run the app host in VS Code, when I try to re-build the service from the other VS Code window, I get the locking issue.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
Yea those multiple instances don’t know about each other so they’ll fight. That’s not really fixable without some outer building orchestrator.

cc @baronfel for ideas

nodes.author: Sjark
nodes.body: It would be really nice if it worked in multi-repo scenarios. Workaround for now is to create a custom command that stops the service, runs dotnet build and starts the service again. This works fine, but would be really nice to just hit build in vs code.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: The solution for that is to create a solution so that VS knows about all of the projects and can properly coordinate builds… OR build elsewhere.

title: Cannot rebuild projects due to exe file being locked

author: galvesribeiro
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When following the [docs to create test projects](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/fundamentals/testing?pivots=xunit) which spin up Aspire services for integration tests, it is not possible to hit a breakpoint and debug the services just like we would when running the Aspire project outside the tests.

Breakpoints on the test code and the AppHost itself are hit just fine. Only the projects orchestrated by the AppHost which are not.

### Expected Behavior

To be able to set breakpoints on the downstream Aspire projects and they would be hit while debugging tests, just as in the normal runtime of Aspire apps.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Follow the docs and add a test project to an existing Aspire solution: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/fundamentals/testing?pivots=xunit
2. Put a break point in any place on the downstream projects. It can be on Program.cs or any code that would be otherwise triggered as part of the tests;
3. Debug the test;
4. Observe that the breakpoint is never hit;

I've tested and reproduced on VSCode and Rider. I have no Windows box to test on Visual Studio tho.

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

Debugging unit tests in rider is a known issue, with a PR already merged into the EAP release of Rider. Here's the link to the issue: https://github.com/JetBrains/aspire-plugin/issues/185

nodes.author: ocallesp
nodes.body:
Test Explorer is for launching the test projects DLL/EXE under the debugger. We observe that the debugger correctly hits breakpoints inside the test.

However, breakpoints in other projects appear to be affected by an issue with the debugger handling debug symbols. It seems there is a mismatch between the .pdb and .dll files.

In the Debug Console, we can see multiple messages like the following:

```
Breakpoint warning: A copy of Program.cs was found in Bug5257.AppHost.dll, but the current source code is different from the version built into Bug5257.AppHost.dll.
To allow this breakpoint to be hit: Add '"requireExactSource": false' to launch.json and restart debugging. - c:\Users\<User>\source\repos\AspireBug5257\Bug5257.ApiService\Program.cs:7
```

Despite this warning, we can confirm `Program.cs` has not changed, yet the debugger incorrectly detects it as modified.

Having this problem in `VS 17.14.9` using the JetBrains test runner `243.0.20241111.161023`, on Aspire SDK `9.4`

Breakpoints in the tests work fine, breakpoints in the fixtured AppHost'd projects are not hit, nor are thrown exceptions caught, but symbols are loaded.

I am able to 'Run Debug' tests then Debugger.Launch() inside the hosted app and force it to attach. `Debugger.IsAttached` is false when launching the tests in debug mode (which obviously is why we are having this problem).

Launching the test with VS Test Runner does allow the breakpoints to bind, so I'm not completely stuck.

Attempts to fix:

 - ❌ Updated JetBrains test runner `251.0.20250617.82607`
 - ✅ Launched with VS Test Runner

nodes.author: LittleLittleCloud
nodes.body: @jamescarter-le Does JetBrains test runner support aspire IDE protocol? VS Test Explorer supports IDE protocol by spinning up an aspire server to work with DCP when you launch aspire tests. This enables testing apphost starting aspire resources using IDE instead of CLI and that's why breakpoints can be bound in VS Test runner.

title: Unable to debug Aspire Resource project while testing

### Is there an existing issue for this?

### Describe the bug

When running the Aspire starter project in VS Code, in WSL, with environment variables "name" or "shell" (NB: lowercase) set to any value, project resources fail to start. Dashboard is up, and I can set breakpoints in the AppHost project.

I get this in the debug console (with "name" set to "nix-shell-env"):

These environment variables are automatically set by the Nix shell, so this prevents me from using Aspire within a Nix development environment. NB: I also get the error without Nix installed, as long as "name" or "shell" are exported.

Running the Aspire app with `dotnet run` works fine.


### Expected Behavior

I expect to be able to debug projects in VS Code run within a Nix development environment.

### Steps To Reproduce

In WSL:
```
mkdir test
cd test
dotnet new aspire-starter
export name=nix-shell-env
code .
```
… then press F5 and select "test.AppHost".

Same thing happen with `export shell=/usr/bin/bash`. Then if I do this:
```
export -n name
export -n shell
code .

title: VS Code debugging in Linux (WSL) doesn’t work when environment variables "name" or "shell" are set

author: ReubenBond
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

When developing an app which includes Python projects, I would like to be able to debug the Python projects when launching from Visual Studio or Visual Studio Code.

There are a couple of things to consider initially:
* Python-only debugging 
* Mixed debugging: debugging Aspire applications involving both Python & .NET (etc) projects

### Describe the solution you'd like

Add support for debugging Python projects to Aspire

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body: fyi @BillHiebert

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: @ReubenBond and/or @samsp-msft - any idea what IDE or dev environment dependencies this would force onto a user? i.e., would they simply need to install the Python workload for Visual Studio and/or have Python tools installed in VS Code? @ReubenBond have you a sample project we could use to test some scenarios?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Generally we care about fleshing out the mechanics to make cross language debugging work. This work title is about python but there are platform features we need to support to make the end to end work

nodes.author: v-croft
nodes.body:
Hi @davidfowl. This is a problem we are now facing... trying to orchestrate with Aspire a solution containing multiple project components in VS Code: Python/Django API, .NET, React/Vite front end.
It does not seem possible to step into either the front end code nor the python code. Nor does it seem possible to even output debug information to the VS Code debug console.
Aspire is great... but there is lots of existing code out there which is not .NET that would benefit from Aspire orchestration and VS Code would seem the correct IDE to enable this with.
Thanks!

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: We know, we will tackle this but we're still fixing lots of other things at the moment, it's mostly a prioritization exercise 😄.

nodes.author: CZEMacLeod
nodes.body:
For the case of Visual Studio (not VSCode) I have a solution for debugging python and .net projects with Aspire available at https://github.com/CZEMacLeod/AspirePythonDebugging

I am not a python developer myself, but when I was trying to get IIS (Express) based ASP.NET 4.x projects working with Aspire, built a package that allows telling the VisualStudio instance running the AspireAppHost to connect for debugging to a resource.

I had a go at NodeJS using the `JavaScript and TypeScript (Chrome DevTools/V8 Inspector)` transport which works, and thought it might be similar for Python. I think the Python integration I ended up with is a little cleaner. With python it uses `debugpy` and the `Python remote (debugpy)` transport.

title: Python debugging support

author: jdasilva-olo
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

If Visual Studio is left running for more than 1 week (7 days), it appears that after midnight the certificate served by the IDE will expire and DCP will not be able to connect.  Apparently, I leave Visual Studio open a lot because I've hit this a few times over the last couple of months.  Restarting Visual Studio fixes the problem.

### Expected Behavior

This is not a high priority but a small quality of life issue.  It would be nice if the resolution were more obvious (like adding a "did you try restarting your IDE" or something similar) or even better if there was some way for Visual Studio to auto-refresh the cert even if I have to ack it in a dialog.

It can be a little difficult to spot when running tests especially because it retries for a while.

### Steps To Reproduce

Any Aspire project will do, but you need to leave the IDE open for over 7 days.

title: IDE Certificate Expires When Visual Studio is Open For a Long Time

author: stefan-van-de-griendt-quandago
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

For reference, I did do a search on `blazor wasm` on **all** issues and found these related ones

1. #1793
But this one seems to be about debugging in the browser, whereas I'm looking for debugging in my IDE.
2. #1418
Seems to be about exactly what I'd like to do but is closed and I can't provide any input there.

The issue at hand is as follows

1. Having a project `Microsoft.NET.Sdk.BlazorWebAssembly`;
2. Put a breakpoint at some code;
3. When debugging the project directly, a debugger attaches just fine, and breakpoints are hit;
4. When debugging via .NET Aspire, seemingly no debugger attaches and breakpoints are **not** hit.

### Expected Behavior

Start a debug session on a .NET Aspire project and being able to debug Blazor WASM projects, just like any other regular .NET project can be debugged.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. dotnet new aspire
2. dotnet new blazorwasm -o Web
3. dotnet sln add Web
4. dotnet add AppHost.AppHost reference Web
5. Add `_ = builder.AddProject<Projects.Web>("web");` to `AppHost.AppHost/Program.cs`
6. Add a breakpoint at `Web/Pages/Counter.razor` in the `IncrementCount` method

When starting a debug session directly on the `Web` project, a browser tab will open up. It will initially say that a debugger is being attached and after that, it will actually load. Going to the Counter page and clicking the button will hit the breakpoint.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/951cadba-e377-4a43-832c-304e6f291780)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/436aca4d-7603-4c79-a6f5-b2087bd68c7d)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a6c58a71-a39b-485d-9e2c-252db32279f0)

When starting a debug session on the `AppHost.AppHost` project, a browser tab will open up. It shows the dashboard and navigating to the `Web` project doesn't show the debugger being attached message and goes straight into the regular loading. Going to the Counter page and clicking the button will **not** hit the breakpoint.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a16247ca-0afa-4591-8296-6627e885d532)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0f81a520-fbd5-40b1-ae9b-108f63d03900)

The very deceiving part is that it does say the debugger is being attached, but in reality, it's not. Here's a screenshot of the scenario with Visual Studio instead. As you can see, then there's no message at all of a debugger being attached. This is also the case for debugging `Web` directly by the way (but then the breakpoints do get hit).
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f04a35e9-7fc2-4d68-898c-e59a272187f6)


### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

`dotnet --info`
```
.NET SDK:

nodes.author: SigurdEEspersen
nodes.body: I've fixed my issue. To other people experiencing this problem: Make sure the launch profile name (e.g. "https") is the same in both the AppHost project and the blazor project or manually provide the launch profile name when adding the blazor project in the AppHost program.cs. I had changed the launch settings name in my blazor application, which resulted in the second browser for the blazor app to not spawn.

nodes.author: JakeRadMSFT

nodes.author: danroth27
nodes.body: @JakeRadMSFT In order to debug a Blazor WebAssembly app, the browser instance needs to have remote debugging enabled and then Visual Studio needs to connect to that browser instance through our .NET debugging proxy. When you run a .NET Aspire app that has a Blazor WebAssembly app, it should launch a separate browser instance specifically for debugging the Blazor WebAssembly app. If debugging the Blazor WebAssembly app with this separate browser instance isn't working, then this would be a bug. Using the browser instance with the .NET Aspire dashboard to debug the Blazor WebAssembly won't work because it hasn't been configured appropriately for remote debugging and this is by design.

nodes.body:
> > In my fresh Aspire template starter app, I have a Web API and also I have added a Blazor WASM app. There is a Blazor WASM window opening with a random port, that seems to be able to hit breakpoints. I can also launch the WASM from the Aspire Dashboard with a fixed port, but this version does not hit breakpoints. I need (at least I think I need) a fixed port because I am using Azure B2C for login, and I need my redirect URIs to be exact matches.
> > As it stands now, if I want to use Aspire, I will have to choose between being able to login to my app without debugging, or debug but without login. Is this the status now, or am I missing something?
> 
> I also have a similar problem, but with an Identity server (OpenIddict based). There I have to register the client callbacks, getting a random port each time makes this registration impossible. If we could at least control the port number used for the window with the Blazor Wasm debugging.

I have similar needs as these use cases so being able to specify the hostname the app should use for the debug tab would be great.

My use case:
I deploy innerloop infrastructure using Crossplane compositions, which includes a local KinD cluster.  I deploy apps to this cluster using devspace.sh.  IdentityServer is thrown in too, and like the comments before me, I rely on proper FQDNs for redirect URIs, and also TLS termination at nginx.

I want to use Aspire but also want to keep as much of my existing infrastructure setup as possible.  To that end, I support a dev opting to only deploy each application's Ingress, ConfigMap and a modified Service resource to support redirection to host.docker.internal and a specific port the relevant Aspire app would run on (the one in the launchsettings.json).

I've added a custom hosting integration the provides an Aspire resource that loads an app's configmap from the cluster, and I reference this from the relevant app so it gets the same environment as it would in the cluster, with some filtering where it makes sense.  This setup means I can present my original app URLs to the dev in the dashboard and the apps work the same as if they were in the cluster, only now I can debug them much easier than say using B2K (deprecated) or Telepresence.

The only sticky point so far is debugging the Blazor WebAssembly client app.  The browser window is launched fine once I figured out the launch profile needed to be renamed - thanks @SigurdEEspersen for that info - but due to my setup needing the app's ingress URL I have to paste it into the address bar of this debug tab.  This works by the way.  The app behaves normally and I can hit client breakpoints.  I just wish I could tell Aspire to use my required URL instead of the random port localhost URL.

nodes.author: markphillips100
nodes.body:
I solved my problem temporarily by adding a redirect middleware to the hosted app.  This redirects any localhost url to the url host that I require, except where the request is for the `/_framework/debug` path.  This allows the browser to establish the socket connection for debugging and the initial localhost random port request gets redirected and from then on all is good.

It would be nicer if I could control it from the Aspire side of things but it'll allow me to debug at least.

nodes.author: devritter
nodes.body: Today I found a solution for this problem. Aspire creates [proxy ports](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/fundamentals/networking-overview#ports-and-proxies) to support replicas. You can verify this default behavior when looking at the environment variables: and your app's console output: --- You can disable this "port proxy" behavior: ```csharp var wasmApp = builder.AddProject("wasmapp") .WithExternalHttpEndpoints() .WithEndpoint("http", x => x.IsProxied = false) // disable per endpoint .WithEndpoint("https", x => x.IsProxied = false) // disable per endpoint .WithReference(apiService) .WaitFor(apiService); // or disable for all endpoints wasmApp.Resource.Annotations.OfType().ToList().ForEach(x => x.IsProxied = false); ``` If you want WASM debugging, you definitely need `"launchBrowser": true` inside `launchSettings.json` as already explained before. And you also need to use that browser instance! Just "ignore" the Aspire browser window for debugging purposes, also don't open the web app from the dashboard links as this will use the wrong browser instance. Your OAuth flows should now have a stable redirect URI. And as a bonus point: the "CSS Hot-Reload" also works again when you use the port from `launchSettings.json` 😉

author: timheuer
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When creating a new Azure Functions project and using 'Enlist in Aspire Orchestration' -- it will fail if the AppHost SDK package has never been used before.

### Expected Behavior

Creating an Azure Function project with orchestration should work.

### Steps To Reproduce

Clear nuget cache (`dotnet nuget locals all -c`)
File...New Azure Function
Check "Enlist in orchestration" checkbox
Fail with (this shows preview 1, but could be rc1 depending on template versions installed):
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6be47a97-1f1b-4a78-a68a-5a371aa20849)

[Workaround]
Create an Aspire app with the apphost sdk on the machine -- this will force a restore and cache the package
the above flow should now work

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body:
Thanks for logging this, @timheuer. I don't think this is isolated to Functions projects, and should be able to be reproduced with any type of project when trying to add Aspire orchestration.

MSBuild SDKs are special type of NuGet packages, and are restored in a special way by both VS and the CLI, as they need to be restored very early in the project evaluation, even before the "real" NuGet package restore. My bet is that this special logic doesn't handle correctly the case where a project that is being dynamically being added to a solution depends on an MSBuild SDK NuGet package which is not in the cache yet. We should further investigate to confirm what the issue is and what the best course of action should be to address it.

cc: @phenning @DamianEdwards

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body: One potential workaround we can consider, is to make sure that every time we insert the Aspire templates into Visual Studio, we also insert the MSBuild SDK into VS's offline cache, so that this issue is less likely to be hit. It would still obviously be potentially hit if people reference a different SDK than the one we inserted in the offline cache.

nodes.author: joperezr
nodes.body: Flagging this as area-tooling since I believe this is a VS specific issue. cc: @bradygaster @JakeRadMSFT

nodes.author: JakeRadMSFT
nodes.body:
@phenning thoughts on this?

@drewnoakes is this an IPA thing?

nodes.author: phenning
nodes.body: Note that this does not currently repro with 9.4 aspire (I ran the clear command before trying to repro). I'm not sure, but in the original repo, if a template pack was installed from the prerelease feed containing 9.1-preview templates on the command line, but Visual Studio did not have the associated pre-release feed configured in NuGet package manager settings. I think we would get into this circumstance in this case.

nodes.author: drewnoakes
nodes.body:
> is this an IPA thing?

Possibly, but it smells of being a chicken/egg problem, at least if we rely on projects telling us what components they need. In this case, if the project doesn't get spun up properly, it wouldn't be able to advertise its requirements. This seems like a general problem, and any solution would/could be general too.

Another option would be to have the template system advertise the capabilities required for any template you're about to instantiate.

author: petrkasnal

nodes.author: captainsafia
nodes.body:
@petrkasnal Thanks for filling a separate issue for this!

So, I think the gist of what you are trying to do is wire up a pre-provisioned Azure Service Bus instance to your Azure Functions project in Aspire?

If so, there's some additional wiring up that you have to do to get it working correctly. The crux of the issue deals with the fact that the key name that the `WithReference` method uses by default to inject the connection string value (`ConnectionStrings_{connectionName}`) does not play nicely with the Azure Functions host. The Azure Functions host expects any value that lives in configuration with this key format to be a connection string, not a fully qualified namespace as shown here.

That's why in Aspire we have resources that implement the [`IResourceWithAzureFunctionsConfig` ](https://source.dot.net/#Aspire.Hosting.Azure/IResourceWithAzureFunctionsConfig.cs,11) interface to dictate what the environment variable that should be used is.

That means when you use `AddConnectionString` to preconfigure values, you should use `WithEnvironment` to inject the resource instead of `WithReference` (_only_ for Azure Functions projects).

For your case, something like this should work:

```csharp
builder.AddAzureFunctionsProject<Projects.AzureFunctionsTest_Functions>("funcapp")
    .WithEnvironment("Messaging__fullyQualifiedNamespace", await messaging.Resource.GetConnectionStringAsync());
```

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
You can simplify that code.

```C#
builder.AddAzureFunctionsProject<Projects.AzureFunctionsTest_Functions>("funcapp")
    .WithEnvironment("Messaging__fullyQualifiedNamespace", messaging);
```

It's important as that will work in both local and deployment scenarios.

nodes.author: petrkasnal
nodes.body:
I'm sorry, I was confusing the connection string. It's not that it doesn't work for ServiceBus/Messaging. It's that it doesn't work in general. I've updated the example repository. And let's say I have a connection string to an external API/database. In short, whatever.

```
builder.AddAzureFunctionsProject<Projects.AzureFunctionsTest_Functions>("funcapp")
    .WithReference(messaging)
    //.WithReference(externalApi) Same problem
//    .WithReference(externalApi2) Same problem
    .WithEnvironment("ConnectionStrings__ExternalApi", externalApi)
    .WithEnvironment("ConnectionStrings__ExternalApi2", externalApi2);
```


However same problem when using WithEnvrionment as well as WithReference. Just be careful every time you run it, it's different. Sometimes the value is taken from Aspire appsettings and sometimes from Azure Function from localsettings.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/10bd3391-e685-44b5-9011-092e6f48df89)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5f3d0236-c924-4c21-bef2-2db3b041c7e0)

nodes.author: captainsafia
nodes.body:
> However same problem when using WithEnvrionment as well as WithReference. Just be careful every time you run it, it's different. Sometimes the value is taken from Aspire appsettings and sometimes from Azure Function from localsettings.

Can you remove the values in the Azure Functions localsettings.json? There's a chance that there might be an ordering issue with the way the values are resolved by the host when it is run.

When using Azure Functions with Aspire, you want Aspire to be the source-of-truth for configuration as much as possible.

nodes.author: petrkasnal
nodes.body: Yes of course if I remove the values from the localsettings it works fine. However, for the WebApi project it is overridden and works automatically.

nodes.author: captainsafia
nodes.body:
> However, for the WebApi project it is overridden and works automatically.

I assume the for your Web API project you're using `appsettings.json`? `localsettings` is unique to the Azure Functions host and it processes the values in that differently. The recommended pattern for config with this integration is to always go through Aspire. Is t here a reason you want the values in localsettings?

nodes.author: petrkasnal
nodes.body: For example, if I wanted to run a function independently. I mean without Aspire.

@captainsafia 

Well, it's not about the messaging. As I wrote, I edited the repository and put in a different connection string. For example for external api or something.

I'm not sure how this interacts with Visual Studio when debugging.

@drewnoakes , @lifengl any ideas?

nodes.author: drewnoakes
phenning
nodes.body:
@rainersigwald , it looks like the error message is coming from here, in the SdkResolverCache. I'm not super familiar with this code, but it doesn't seem like it handles updating very well.  What is the lifetime of the cache/wrapper?  Would multiple design time builds triggered by changes to the project share the same cache?  If so, I think this is where the problem might be.

https://github.com/dotnet/msbuild/blob/9b630d948a94ebb552df81d0d32bcdfc2841d978/src/Build/BackEnd/Components/SdkResolution/SdkResolverCachingWrapper.cs#L71

nodes.author: phenning
nodes.body: I've also ruled out P2P being a factor, as this repros with a simply only having an AppHost project in the solution.

nodes.author: rainersigwald
nodes.body: The lifetime of the cache is a single build invocation (e.g. on the command line a whole solution or the transitive closure of a project). In VS this is controlled by an [`EvaluationContext`](https://learn.microsoft.com/dotnet/api/microsoft.build.evaluation.context.evaluationcontext) that I believe is owned at the CPS layer, and should ideally be refreshed with this kind of change.

author: bradygaster
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

The summary of this issue is that .NET projects that have already been orchestrated with Aspire can't be included in subsequent solutions orchestrated with Aspire unless the solution's `App Host` and `Defaults` projects are deleted or the project-to-be-included is moved into another directory. Whilst an edge case, this issue could be a manifestation of the "multi-repo scenario," or any multi-developer scenario in which:

1. one developer is primarily responsible for the orchestration (thus, the `App Host` and `Defaults` projects) and other developers build node projects (APIs, front end web apps, and so forth)
2. individual developers work on individual node projects without much consideration beyond their individual nodes for what's included in the `App Host` or `Defaults` projects, and they worry about it later during an integration phase of their release process

### Expected Behavior

When a developer is working on a .NET Aspire solution and they add a project to the solution that's in another .NET Aspire solution, the project references to the `Defaults` project is updated appropriately following orchestration and everything builds and runs once the project has been orchestrated into the destination .NET Aspire solution. 

### Steps To Reproduce

This repro takes a Visual Studio approach, but the build exception is resident when replicating this process via the command line, too. 

1. Create a new Aspire Starter App named `DestinationApp` at [for example] `c:\src\TheApp\DestinationApp\DestinationApp.sln` in a new instance of Visual Studio
2. Create a new Empter Aspire App named `NewIncomingAppNode` at [given example in step 1]: `c:\src\TheApp\NewIncomingAppNode\NewIncomingAppNode.csproj` in a second instance of Visual Studio
3. Add a new Web Api project named `TheApi` to the `NewIncomingAppNode` solution
4. Close the `NewIncomingAppNode` solution and go back to the `DestinationApp` solution's instance of Visual Studio
5. Add the `TheApi` project to the `DestinationApp` solution via the "Add -> Existing Project" menu in Visual Studio
6. Right-click `TheApi` project and "Add Aspire Orchestration" and note VS tells you it's going to use the `App Host` and `Defaults` project in the existing solution
7. Note the `TheApi` project has been added to the `App Host` project's `Program.cs`
8. You may need to edit the `TheApi.csproj` file if both `Defaults` projects have been added. You'd need to change: 

   ```
   <ItemGroup>
     <ProjectReference Include="..\..\Destination\Destination\Destination.ServiceDefaults\Destination.ServiceDefaults.csproj" />
     <ProjectReference Include="..\NewIncomingAppNode.ServiceDefaults\NewIncomingAppNode.ServiceDefaults.csproj" />
   </ItemGroup>
   ```

   into: 

   ```
   <ItemGroup>
     <ProjectReference Include="..\..\Destination\Destination\Destination.ServiceDefaults\Destination.ServiceDefaults.csproj" />
   </ItemGroup>
   ```

9. F5 the solution

### Exceptions (if any)

`Metadata file 'C:\src\TheApp\NewIncomingAppNode\NewIncomingAppNode.ServiceDefaults\obj\Debug\net9.0\ref\NewIncomingAppNode.ServiceDefaults.dll' could not be found`

### .NET Version info

```
.NET SDK:
 Version:           9.0.200-preview.0.24611.4
 Commit:            6d67e2a457
 Workload version:  9.0.200-manifests.6448c051
 MSBuild version:   17.13.0-preview-24569-04+8f6b8ad0a

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.26100
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\9.0.200-preview.0.24611.4\

.NET workloads installed:
 [aspire]
   Installation Source: VS 17.13.35707.81, VS 17.13.35617.110
   Manifest Version:    8.2.2/8.0.100
   Manifest Path:       C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk-manifests\8.0.100\microsoft.net.sdk.aspire\8.2.2\WorkloadManifest.json
   Install Type:              Msi

Configured to use loose manifests when installing new manifests.

Host:
  Version:      9.0.0
  Architecture: x64
  Commit:       9d5a6a9aa4

.NET SDKs installed:
  9.0.200-preview.0.24575.35 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
  9.0.200-preview.0.24611.4 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]

.NET runtimes installed:
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 8.0.11 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 9.0.0 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 8.0.11 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 9.0.0 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 8.0.11 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]
  Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 9.0.0 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App]
```

### Anything else?

To work around this issue, go to the `C:\src\TheApp\NewIncomingAppNode` folder and delete the `App Host` and `Defaults` projects. Then, rebuilding/running the `Destination` solution works. This is sub-optimal, as a developer working on the incoming app might prefer to work on their app in an isolated manner; they may have tests set up already, custom code in their `App Host` they're not finished testing, or anything else.

title: .NET Aspire solutions can't build when their projects are in folders with source trees inclusive of other Aspire App Host/Defaults projects

author: karolz-ms

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
@DamianEdwards @tmat @danegsta @davidfowl FYI

Personally I like option 2 the best but can be convinced to go with any of them. Open to other suggestions.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: Also @rafaelldi please share your thoughts!

nodes.author: rafaelldi
nodes.body:
Hello! Thanks for the mention! Now in our plugin we generate an environment variable `DOTNET_DASHBOARD_FRONTEND_BROWSERTOKEN` and run the host project with it. Then we use this token to open a browser. But I can change this behavior by using the DCP response instead.

In my opinion, options 1 and 3 can be confusing because the proposed `launch_url` refers to the entire solution running under a particular `AspireHost` and not to individual .NET projects within the solution (as far as I understand). Each individual project itself has an `applicationUrl` in the `launchSettings.json` file and these two URLs (`launch_url` and `applicationUrl`) can be mixed up. I like the second option better.

> If the browser URL contains secrets (such as is the case with Aspire dashboard URL), it probably makes sense to only add it to the URL if the session with the IDE is secured 

To be honest, I still don't use a certificate when connecting DCP in the plugin. Mainly because for some users (e.g. with different linux distributions), it can be challenging to configure everything. And we only support a local scenario, and if your local machine is compromised, the certificate probably won't help. So I would ask to add a token to the response even in an unsecured session. For example, if the author of the IDE toolkit fully understands the risks and thinks it's ok to use an insecure connection in their case.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: @adamint no, we haven't done any work yet to make this happen, sorry. Has this issue come up in some context recently?

nodes.author: famda
nodes.body: I've tested this using the React App with Asp Net Core (typescript) template. For this to work it's necessary to make a few changes on the project: On the Server project: - Install the nuget package "Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaProxy"; - Add the environment variable "ASPNETCORE_HOSTINGSTARTUPASSEMBLIES" with "Microsoft.AspNetCore.SpaProxy" on launch settings profile; - On .csproj file add: ``` npm run dev ..\portal.client https://localhost:54705 ``` To know which address you should use, it is easier to run only the client project the first time to see the port that is assigned to the client (which is different from the Server project). On the Aspire AppHost: - Just add the project like a normal c# project: `builder.AddProject("portal-server").WithExternalHttpEndpoints();` On the Aspire dashboard will show the resource with the Server urls and by navigating there the proxy will fire and redirect to the client without issues automatically: @davidfowl I don't know if this is the best approach but this works. However, less friction here is appreciated. :) What do you think?

nodes.author: maddymontaquila
nodes.body: Is there a reason you're doing it this way instead of just using a vanilla JS/React app and AddNpmApp() ? The project system for JS is super helpful for .NET devs in VS but is somewhat less useful when you have Aspire to do a lot of the magic JSPS is doing in IDE.

nodes.author: famda
nodes.body:
It is mostly for security reasons and for personal preference. I like the server side to be asp net core and this uses a BFF pattern with session caching.
This works fine with Aspire.

### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When attempting to add package `Aspire.Hosting.MongoDB` to my AppHost project [per the instructions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/database/mongodb-integration?tabs=dotnet-cli#hosting-integration), the installation is rolled back with the following errors:
```text
Restoring packages for e:\dev\AspireApp2\AspireApp2.AppHost\AspireApp2.AppHost.csproj...
  CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3/vulnerabilities/index.json
  CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-vulnerabilities/2025.01.24.05.38.39/vulnerability.base.json
  CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-vulnerabilities/2025.01.24.05.38.39/2025.01.27.11.38.48/vulnerability.update.json

NU1202: Package System.Buffers 4.5.1 is not compatible with net9.0 (.NETCoreApp,Version=v9.0). Package System.Buffers 4.5.1 does not support any target frameworks.
Package restore failed. Rolling back package changes for 'AspireApp2.AppHost'.
```

This happens whether adding via the NuGet package manager in VS 2022 or via the command line using `dotnet add package Aspire.Hosting.MongoDB`

I tested this using a personal project as well as a new project created using the ".NET Aspire Starter App" template. 

### Expected Behavior

Able to add the `Aspire.Hosting.MongoDB` package as described in the [MongoDB Aspire Integration docs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/aspire/database/mongodb-integration?tabs=dotnet-cli#hosting-integration).

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create a new project using the ".NET Aspire Starter App" template.
2. Select Framework .NET 9.0 (selection for Redis caching does not matter, issue happens with this checked or unchecked)
3. Once the project is created, verify it runs using F5
4. Add `Aspire.Hosting.MongoDB` package using either "Manage Packages for Solution" in VS 2022 IDE or via command line
5. Observe errors in the output and Error List windows.

Example repo located at [TallBaldGeek/AspireMongoDBPackageIssue](https://github.com/TallBaldGeek/AspireMongoDBPackageIssue). (It's just the results of steps 1-3 above but including in case it helps)

author: jongio
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

After the user creates a new Aspire project from a template it would be good to let them know what to do next.  If they hit F5, they are presented with the option to run C#, which makes sense, but then they are presented with option to run all of the projects in the solution, and it may not be apparent that they need to run the AppHost project, especially for new users.



### Describe the solution you'd like

Suggest adding a launch.json with the AppHost Default Configuration wired up.  Or a "Next Steps" md file that can help them through that.  Also, recommend adding that they will likely need to close down all browsers after installing the dev cert.

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards thoughts?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
Yeah VS has the Aspire "starter" page that is auto-displayed after creating Aspire projects but we don't have anything anywhere else. I think a `nextsteps.md` or something similar could be interesting, especially if we can figure out how to make it auto-open so it's presented more "forcibly" as the next thing the user should read (i.e. in VS Code, etc.). I'm curious as to whether there's already an established pattern or standard for this kind of thing?

RE the "if they hit F5 they have to select C#, etc." I'm empathetic to that but the VS Code launch space is kinda complex, with some stacks preferring to default to dynamic (in-memory) launch providers vs. being driven by `launch.json`/`tasks.json`. Not sure how to resolve that.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Some investigation from ChatGPT: https://chatgpt.com/share/6855d6e6-5b98-8012-8dc8-0b9a611807ed

title: Add "Next Steps" to Aspire Template Creation

author: giangcoi48k
body:
Normally, when I press **F5** to debug a .NET Core project, it opens a new tab in my browser. This is because I have unticked the setting "**Stop debugger when browser window is closed...**" in Visual Studio.

However, when I debug an **Aspire AppHost** project, it always opens a **new browser window** instead of a new tab, which is very annoying.

Is there a way to configure it so that it opens in a new tab instead of a new window?

Thanks in advance!

nodes.author: hjrb
nodes.body: Also: the Apsire dashboard opens a new browser tab on debugging. It does not close the tab at the end of the debug session but leaves it open - which is a good behavior. But the next debug session again open a new tab and after a while there a many tabs open with the same Aspire dashboard. This would all be not such a big problem if "Hot Reload" would finally be working. But is simply does not. Don't ask what is not working. The answer: everything. And you guys know it.

title: Prevent Aspire AppHost from opening a new browser window when debugging

author: bradygaster
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

We shipped a preview of the "Add Aspire Orchestration" feature in VS code, but there are still some remaining rough edges we need to smooth out to make the experience as easy as possible for customers to "Aspirify" their .NET projects. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

Below is a list of the improvements we need to make: 

* [ ] Today, we aren't injecting code into the App Host project's `program.cs` file like we do when customers use the Add Orchestration feature in VS, and we should augment the VS Code functionality so it has parity with the code injection we perform in Visual Studio. 
* [ ] Prefix the App Host and Service Defaults projects. In the case of a Razor project named `MyRazorProject`, for example, the App Host project's name should be `MyRazorProject.AppHost` and the service defaults project should be named `MyRazorProject.ServiceDefaults`. We should continue to allow the customer the ability to change this name and omit the prefix if they desire. 
* [ ] Today there seems to be a visible delay when clicking the Add Orchestration menu item in VS Code. We should try to optimize the experience and mitigate this delay if possible. 
* [ ] Once a solution has been Aspire Orchestrated, we should hide the Add Orchestration menu item to mitigate customers inadvertently repeating the process. 
* [ ] If a customer has a solution composed of a single `.csproj` file and they use the Add Orchestration gesture, by default the App Host and Service Defaults projects and dropped into the same folder as the project's source code. The resultant solution **will not build** because the App Host and Service Defaults project folders are child folders of the original project's folder. This causes build breaks that aren't easy to troubleshoot until one sees the folder structure in a file explorer. We should mitigate this when customers are orchestrating single-project solutions - either decide on a subfolder in which the Aspire App Host and Service Defaults projects get dropped, block the user until they move the `.sln` up a level. 
* [ ] Once we implement all of the items in this list, we should remove the "Preview" moniker from the Add Orchestration menu item in VS Code. 
* [ ] Item #6647
* [ ] Item #7973

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: cc @jamesmontemagno - As promised, here's an issue summarizing the feedback you provided and that I was able to reproduce. Can you let me know if I missed anything, and I'll get it added to the list. cc @JakeRadMSFT fyi

nodes.author: jamesmontemagno
nodes.body:
This looks great. A few things I found were:

* Things didn't work without the SLN with the new "solutionless option" in VS Code, so looks like you cover it here, but there is a bug that I reported to them.
* Allow users to pick a folder where AppHost/Service Defaults are created. This is sort of the same above.
* We shoudl injcted code into each orchestrated project for AddServiceDefaults and MapEndpoints

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: Thanks @jamesmontemagno - i think i covered the injected code one, too. thanks for testing it out and giving us an opportunity to improve the experience.

nodes.author: bradygaster
nodes.body: @LittleLittleCloud and @JakeRadMSFT - after chatting with @jamesmontemagno, this one is ready for triage. Marking this as a high, but, fully expect this to be post-9.1, ideally, 9.2.

nodes.body: Related item: #6647

author: aL3891
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Sometimes I debug a method in a common library that is called from multiple projects, but only one of them is producing the problem i'm trying to solve. In this case my breakpoint will be hit with many irrelevant cases.

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be handy to be able to detach and reattach the debugger from the dashboard. This can be done manually in visual studio but having it in the dashboard would be convenient. Also there could be the possibility to detach / reattach the debugger from all the projects with a single action in the dashboard
title: Dashboard command to detach and reattach the debugger

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

I'm encountering 2 issues causing the dashboard to failing to load across when I restart my app hosts.  This is happening across several app hosts.

First time I run my app, the dashboard is fine, but subsequent times, restarting my app host in visual studio usually results in the dashboard loading with an error state, although occasionally it will load fine first time.  After a refresh the dashboard loads fine

I do notice when this happens, the browser window is opened long before the `Login to the dashboard at https://localhost:17079/login?t=WHATEVER` log is logged, combine this with a refresh fixing things makes me suspect it's an issue with the dashboard browser window being opened a little prematurely.

I also don't recall having this with earlier versions of preview 1, but I have since upgraded to VS 17.13.0, so perhaps it's a VS issue rather than aspire?

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dc03bbce-2d46-4fe1-805c-f08fe36923fb)

Occasionally however the dashboard will totally fail to load on a restart with a connection refused
When this happens, I get a `System.IO.IOException: Failed to bind to address https://127.0.0.1:17079: address already in use.` in my app host console (with `"https://localhost:17079;http://localhost:15214"` being hte `applciationUrl` in `launchsettings.json`. The dashboard should load
