title: 9.1 Dashboard not loading after restarting project in Visual Studio

author: oshpak92
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Dacpac file can't be found for the SqlProject added as a project reference in debug mode.

Error:

> SQL Server Database project package not found at path C:\Users\Oshpa\source\repos\TestSqlSdkProj\SqlProject\bin\Release\SqlProject.dacpac.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/acf56733-be5a-4d39-9b83-7de40cd6b022)

It always tries to pick a Dacpac from the 'Release' folder.

The test project is attached below:

[TestSqlSdkProj.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19016237/TestSqlSdkProj.zip)

### Expected Behavior

If the Aspire host starts in debug mode and the SqlProject is added as a project reference, it should look for a Dacpac in the debug folder.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Create aspire host project
2. Update aspire to the latest version
3. Create SQL SDK project
4. Add SQL project as a project reference to aspire host
5. Add SQL project to the aspire host builder
`var builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

var database = builder.AddSqlServer("sql-server")
    .AddDatabase("test-db");

builder.AddSqlProject<Projects.SqlProject>("test-db-migrations")
    .WithReference(database);

builder.Build().Run();`

6. Run host application in debug mode

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

title: Aspire uses the 'Release' folder to find the Dacpac file of the referenced SqlProject

author: v-elenafeng
body:
**REGRESSION INFO**: Not a regression

**INSTALL STEPS**

1. Clean machine: Win11 x64 ENU
2. Install SDK 9.0.200 (latest-released-version)
3. Install Aspire templates 9.1 (latest-released-version)
    - `dotnet new install Aspire.ProjectTemplates`
4. Install VS Code + C# Dev Kit extension (latest pre-release version 1.17.48)

**REPRO STEPS**

1. Using VS Code, create new 9.0 .NET Aspire Starter App > `AspireApp1`
2. In Solution Explorer, right-click solution node > New Project > 9.0 ASP.NET Web App (Razor Pages) > `WebApplication1` > Default directory > Create
3. In Solution Explorer, right-click solution node > Add .NET Aspire Orchestration > select WebApplication1 as the project to be orchestrated.
4. For the names of AppHost and ServiceDefaults projects, set the values to be WebApplication1.AppHost and WebApplication1.ServiceDefaults.

**ACTUAL**
WebApplication1.AppHost and WebApplication1.ServiceDefaults are created instead of being added to the existing Orchestration.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/088f1203-69c0-473a-b9d6-5ab7dd5bfc2d)

**EXPECTED**
Similar to what VS does, AspireApp1.AppHost will be updated to add WebApplication1 to it.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/05d772b4-e230-4cbd-bb08-c8c7acfae189)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/283d6be6-bdb9-4ee4-b813-b2a299e83f75)

title: [WebToolsE2E] Using VS Code C# Dev Kit, when adding a web project to an Aspire solution and then adding the web project to .NET Aspire Orchestration, it does not add to the existing Orchestration but creates a new one.

author: v-elenafeng
body:
**REGRESSION INFO**: Not a regression

**INSTALL STEPS**

1. Clean machine: Win11 x64 ENU
2. Install SDK 9.0.200 (latest-released-version)
3. Install Aspire templates 9.1 (latest-released-version)
    - `dotnet new install Aspire.ProjectTemplates`
4. Install VS Code + C# Dev Kit extension (latest pre-release version 1.17.48)
5. Install the latest released Azure Functions Extension

**REPRO STEPS**

1. Using VS Code, select Azure Functions explorer > Create Function > .NET 9.0 Isolated > HTTP trigger > `FunctionApp1` > Select "Function" > Select "Open in current windows".
2. Go to Explorer tab, right-click solution node > Add .NET Aspire Orchestration > select `FunctionApp1` as the project to be orchestrated.
3. For the names of AppHost and ServiceDefaults projects, set the values to be `FunctionApp1.AppHost` and `FunctionApp1.ServiceDefaults`.

**ACTUAL**
Aspire orchestration support gets added but it is incomplete

1. In the Program.cs of `FunctionApp1.AppHost`, the critical line of adding the function app project to the IDistributedApplicationBuilder is missing. Without this line, the dashboard will be blank when we run the AppHost.
  
    ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3c1f017b-7b39-4c03-af31-d7073aa32312)

2. In the `FunctionApp1.AppHost.csproj` file, the package 'Aspire.Hosting.Azure.Functions' is missing

    ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f39fd6a1-64c2-4f2a-9be0-720124e00905)

**EXPECTED**
Missing orchestration support code and function package should get properly added.

1. In the Program.cs of `FunctionApp1.AppHost`, we should add the function app project to the IDistributedApplicationBuilder as follows.
 
    ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1fae241b-e77b-4741-8950-169ee6f431e4)

2. In the `FunctionApp1.AppHost.csproj` file, the package 'Aspire.Hosting.Azure.Functions' should be installed automatically.

    ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/591541cb-c657-4018-82e5-f7c043e673fe)

author: v-yuannie
body:
**REGRESSION INFO**: Not a regression

**INSTALL STEPS**
1. Clean machine: Win11 x64 ENU
1. Install SDK 9.0.201 (latest-released-version)
1. Install Aspire templates 9.1 (latest-released-version)
    - `dotnet new install Aspire.ProjectTemplates`
1. Install VS Code + C# Dev Kit extension (latest pre-release version 1.17.48)

**REPRO STEPS**
1. Using VS Code, create new 9.0 .NET Aspire Starter App > `AspireApp1`
2. In Solution Explorer, right-click `AspireApp1.Web` project > Add NuGet Package > Aspire.Azure.Storage.Blobs > add a component 
3. Open appsettings.json > make changes related to Aspire component

**ACTUAL**
There is no intellisense for Aspire-related changes
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/31fa47c4-7cee-4296-a116-de47538d0c8a)

**EXPECTED**
Similar to what VS does, it will get intellisense for Aspire-related changes 
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d26dd77b-6911-4c99-b1e4-9981aa80f38d)

nodes.author: claudiaregio
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards What configuration goes under the Aspire category? Is this necessary for VS Code?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Yeah this is a gap with our VS Code experience today when compared to VS. We did specific work in VS to enable this feature whereby Aspire client integration packages can contribute to the overall JSON schema for the *appsettings.json* file and while the intention was to push that logic down into the .NET SDK itself (and thus enable it everywhere) it never happened. For an example of the kind of thing that shows up in this configuration section see the README.md of Aspire client integration packages, e.g. https://www.nuget.org/packages/Aspire.Npgsql#readme-body-tab: IMO we should do what we originally intended and make this feature general-purpose for any referenced packaged to be able to contribute to the JSON schema for *appsettings.json*. /Cc @eerhardt @JakeRadMSFT

title: [WebToolsE2E] Using VS Code C# Dev Kit, there is no IntelliSense for JSON editing when configuring Aspire integrations

author: danroth27
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

I created a Blazor WebAssembly Standalone App in VS 17.13.5 targeting .NET 9 and selected the project template option to enlist it in a .NET Aspire orchestration. The generated solution contained the standalone Blazor WebAssembly app, the AppHost project, and the ServiceDefaults project. However, it didn't add the Blazor WebAssembly app to the app host. If I manually add the project reference to the Blazor WebAssembly project and add `builder.AddProject<BlazorApp4>("client");` to the AppHost project, it seems to work fine.

### Expected Behavior

I assume the Blazor WebAssembly app should be added to the AppHost so that when you run the AppHost project the Blazor WebAssembly app also starts and shows up in the Aspire dashboard.

### Steps To Reproduce

- Create a Blazor WebAssembly Standalone App project, selecting the option to Enlist in a .NET Aspire orchestration.

### Exceptions (if any)

None

### .NET Version info

9.0.201

### Anything else?

Nope

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: FYI @JakeRadMSFT

nodes.author: RichardReukemaOptimus
nodes.body:
I tried something similar due to a unique client request. They wanted a WASM client, but to interact with an API that was not hosted by the WASM server-side (host? I always struggle with this terminology, as Blazor WASM cannot exist with a server side, and then get into Blazor Server - so I call them Blazor WASM, and Blazor Server, where Blazor WASM Server and Blazor WASM Client)

The problem was that I thought I could use Aspire to set up the Blazor WASM Client with the URL of the API.  However, I determined that the appsettings.json is in the root folder, and served as a static file.  If I was to send the URL of the API to the client, I would have to dynamically update that file, and then have the client pull it down to read locally - not a good option IMO.

So I elected to host a single endpoint on the Blazor WASM Server, which would respond with an IConfiguration provider for either JSON or an environmental variable.  Locally, I use Aspire to start the Blazor and API projects.  When the WASM client starts, it asks the origin server for the API url, which is serves. I then use a named API Client to ensure all HTTP clients begin with a base URL of the API project.

I could use Aspire to integrate the API URL into the Blazor WASM server project, but I have not yet explored how that would work with Aspire deploying to the cloud.

nodes.author: webprofusion-chrisc
nodes.body:
Also looking for a way to do this, our Blazor WASM app calls a separate API (which is already in an aspire host) and it would be good to add the WASM app into the aspire host to see the full trace from app from API to the other parts of the backend. 

Actually configuring the WASM app via aspire would have it's challenges (like rewriting the wwwroot\appsettings.json so the httpclient in the app can point to the aspire hosted API dynamically as @RichardReukemaOptimus states).

For me this is driven by wanting to see end to end tracing, logging and metric when I fire up the app.

nodes.author: RichardReukemaOptimus
nodes.body:
I actually watched a Daniel royal video the other day, and thought I would revisit this. It was on build 2025 where he was showing new .net9 features.

Basically he put the api layer first, using the name of solution "weatherAPI" in the name.

In the blazor app, in the base address for the api client of the api, used the same name for the base address of https://weatherAPI ! (No local host, or azure)

when aspire started, it changed the base api address with the host address it found.


Magic strings! I would create a const in the aspire service and use that for both places.

Haven't tried it yet, but it's on my todo list.

title: Debug publish mode

author: karolz-ms
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

### Scenario
1. Run Aspire application from Visual Studio or VS Code.
2. Switch to VS, right-click on one of the projects that belong to the running application, choose "Rebuild"
3. Observe Aspire dashboard

### Expected
The dashboard should indicate that the project is not running when it is being rebuild
- Resource state should be different from "Running"
- Process ID should disappear (the old process ID is no longer valid)
- The project should be considered "unhealthy"

### Actual
When the project is being rebuilt, there is no change to the project state in Aspire dashboard. This includes the case if the rebuild fails, which may take developer a long time to remedy.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I propose we introduce a new state for projects/Executables: Suspended

1. When rebuild starts, the Executable goes into Suspended state. There is new notification type for this that the IDE sends to DCP, which in turn notifies the Aspire dashboard.
2. The IDE needs to send a Suspended notification for all active debug sessions that are affected by project rebuild.
3. In Suspended state 
    a. The project/Executable is not running. Process ID is no longer available.
    b. The project is considered unhealthy.
    b. Dashboard can still request logs, but stop/restart gestures should be disabled.
4. From Suspended state the Executable can only transition to Exited state, or Running state (upon receiving Session Terminated, or Process Restarted notifications, respectively).

### Additional context

The work required here spans DCP, IDE execution protocol, VS/VS Code/other IDEs that might support this scenario, Aspire dashboard and Aspire resource health.

@LittleLittleCloud @danegsta @JakeRadMSFT @JamesNK @adamint @rafaelldi FYI

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
Changing target framework to 9.0 still results in the same error (same assembly name and version).

Launching from CLI (dotnet run) does work.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: That looks like your visual studio is not in good shape. Can you run other non aspire projects ?

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
Other projects run fine.

Just to be sure I'll cleanly reinstall. Will report back

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
@davidfowl I've uninstalled and reinstalled Visual Studio with ASP.NET and Azure workloads, the issue remains with the same assembly name as mentioned. The error only appears when starting an Aspire project.

Are there any Visual Studio logs i can check?

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body: I did another uninstall of visual studio, deleted every .net sdk and runtime from my pc and reinstalled VS + .net sdk; I still get the same error.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @bradygaster @JakeRadMSFT can you help here?

nodes.author: LittleLittleCloud
nodes.body:
@ikkentim Can you upgrade to VS 17.14.3 (released yesterday) and give another shot, that version works on my compute

If you still get the same error, could you do us a favor and upload servicehub logs
- remove all logs from `%temp%servicehub`
- restart VS and reproduce the error
- upload all logs under `%temp%servicehub`

Thanks @ikkentim from the log it doesn't seem to relevant to aspire server,, could you try starting a normal web project and see if it works.

For example, if you are testing using aspire-starter project template, select `Web` as starter project and hit `control-f5` from VS

nodes.author: tarekgh
nodes.body:
@RikkiGibson 

Do you think this is related to the compiler (version)? `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.JsonConsoleFormatterOptions.Configure` supposes to be calling the generated intercepted call of the `configuration.Bind`? 

```
   at Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.SourceGeneration.<BindingExtensions_g>FC276FD7C89D1ED0B2B3E96BAC8F157FABB86A642EAABC54639B357A857C01D08__BindingExtensions.BindCore
   at Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.SourceGeneration.<BindingExtensions_g>FC276FD7C89D1ED0B2B3E96BAC8F157FABB86A642EAABC54639B357A857C01D08__BindingExtensions.Bind_JsonConsoleFormatterOptions(IConfiguration configuration, Object instance)
   at Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.JsonConsoleFormatterOptions.Configure(IConfiguration configuration)
```

and getting 

```
 System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder, Version=8.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'. The system cannot find the file specified.
```

nodes.author: RikkiGibson
nodes.body:
This doesn't look like a scenario where a compiler version upgrade would break things. I do not think we have taken any changes to interceptors implementation in the past 6 months.

But, I'm not completely following what is broken here. Are the interceptors expected to be present in this scenario? Is the `BindCore` call supposed to cause assembly `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder` to load?

nodes.author: tarekgh
tarekgh
nodes.body: CC @eerhardt

nodes.author: eerhardt
nodes.body: Where is `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` getting loaded from? Can someone attach a debugger and look to see where that assembly gets loaded? The `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder` assembly should be right next to it.

nodes.author: tarekgh
nodes.body: Looking at the shared solution https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/9524#issuecomment-2936746381 I am seeing both `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` and  `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder` exist in the folder `AspireApp3\AspireApp3.AppHost\bin\Debug\net8.0`

nodes.author: tarekgh
nodes.body:
Looking at the deps file, I am not seeing `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions` is listed there at all while the Binder library depends on it. Looking at the output folder and not seeing it there either. I think this could be the problem that cannot load the Binder library as not finding all its dependencies. 

@ikkentim could you explicitly reference [`Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions/8.0.0) in the `AspireApp3.AppHost` and see if will make any difference?

Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.dll	Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.dll	C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\Common7\ServiceHub\Hosts\ServiceHub.Host.dotnet.x64\..\..\SharedAssemblies\Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.dll	Yes	No	Skipped loading symbols.		123	9.00.24.52809	<Unknown>	00007FFE87720000-00007FFE87736000	[40092] ServiceHub.Host.dotnet.x64.exe	[1] clrhost

Notice where those assemblies are being loaded from: 

`C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\Common7\ServiceHub\Hosts\ServiceHub.Host.dotnet.x64\..\..\SharedAssemblies`

But then:

```
Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.dll	Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.dll	C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\dotnet\net8.0\runtime\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App\8.0.17\Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.dll	Yes	No	Skipped loading symbols.		138	8.00.1024.46610	<Unknown>	00007FFE825C0000-00007FFE825E4000	[40092] ServiceHub.Host.dotnet.x64.exe	[1] clrhost	
```

`C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\dotnet\net8.0\runtime\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App\8.0.17\`

So maybe there is a mismatch between the Microsoft.Extensions.* assemblies in those 2 folders?

nodes.body:
I copied `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.dll` v8.0.7 into `Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies`. now the Aspire project will run. This obviously isn't a permanent solution.

To me it isn't clear yet why `runtime\(..)\Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` v8.x fails to find the Configuration Binder that's next to it.


> @LittleLittleCloud - do you know why the 9.0 version would be in C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies?

I don't know for sure but I'd guess that ServiceHub consumes v9 Extensions since a recent VS update. AFAIK Extension packages should be update-able independent of runtime version.

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
Looks like ServiceHub has a `SharedAssemblyLoader` to load `SharedAssemblies` using the `AssemblyLoadContext.Default.Resolving` event.

I've logged the assemblies it resolves, if it is any help.

Note that most of these attempt to load a Version=8.x assembly, but it is resolved to a SharedAssembly, which is v9.


(note: I attached the debugger after the Aspire project was loaded, so it might have already loaded assemblies from SharedAssemblies before I started logging)

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
> To me it isn't clear yet why `runtime\(..)\Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` v8.x fails to find the Configuration Binder that's next to it.
> 
> > [@LittleLittleCloud](https://github.com/LittleLittleCloud) - do you know why the 9.0 version would be in C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Professional\Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies?
> 
> I don't know for sure but I'd guess that ServiceHub consumes v9 Extensions since a recent VS update. AFAIK Extension packages should be update-able independent of runtime version.



`Microsoft.WebTools.AspireServer` uses all 8.0.0.0 versions of assemblies (`MS.AspNetCore.*`, `MS.E.*`, `System.*`). Since it is loaded into the `ServiceHub.Host.dotnet.x64` which references v9 assemblies (through `SharedAssemblyLoader`), we end up in a situation where v9 assemblies are loaded while v8 assemblies are referenced.



Only thing I don't yet understand is why it is only broken for me...

nodes.author: tarekgh
nodes.body:
> To me it isn't clear yet why runtime\(..)\Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console v8.x fails to find the Configuration Binder that's next to it.

`Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` depends on `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder`, which in turn depends on `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions`. The version of `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` being used is v8.0, which requires `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder` v8 — and that version is available.

However, when the runtime attempts to load `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder` v8, it also tries to load `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions` v8. At this point, `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions` v9 is already loaded in the process, and the runtime does not allow multiple versions of the same assembly to be loaded simultaneously. This results in a version conflict.

nodes.author: tarekgh
nodes.body: @LittleLittleCloud I assume you'll follow up here to get this fixed?

nodes.author: LittleLittleCloud
nodes.body:
> I copied Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.dll v8.0.7 into Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies. now the Aspire project will run. This obviously isn't a permanent solution.

We can add `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.dll` to shared assemblies folder, in the long term, servicehub team is working on adding full transitive closure of BCL to shared assemblies folder, which would mitigate such kind of missing assembly issues in a better way

FYI @MarkOsborneMS @JakeRadMSFT

nodes.author: tarekgh
nodes.body:
> We can add `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.dll` to shared assemblies folder

Are you suggesting moving it to `Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies`? If so, I’m not sure how that would resolve the issue. `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` would still be loaded as version 8, which depends on version 8 of both `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.dll` and `Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions.dll`.
From what I understand, the assemblies in `Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies` are version 9. Or are you also suggesting that `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console` be moved there as well?

The core issue seems to be that we’re loading mixed versions of Microsoft.Extensions libraries within the same process. I believe the proper solution is to align all these libraries to the same version to avoid conflicts and ensure compatibility.

nodes.author: LittleLittleCloud
nodes.body:
> Are you suggesting moving it to Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies? If so, I’m not sure how that would resolve the issue. Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console would still be loaded as version 8, which depends on version 8 of both Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Binder.dll and Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions.dll.
From what I understand, the assemblies in Common7\ServiceHub\SharedAssemblies are version 9. Or are you also suggesting that Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console be moved there as well?

Yeah, `Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console.dll` would also needed to be moved there as well.

> The core issue seems to be that we’re loading mixed versions of Microsoft.Extensions libraries within the same process. I believe the proper solution is to align all these libraries to the same version to avoid conflicts and ensure compatibility.

My understand is it's under consideration? @MarkOsborneMS any comment?

nodes.author: MarkOsborneMS
nodes.body: The current approach is that only the required assemblies and their dependencies have been added to SharedAssemblies, but that makes finding and fixing any missing assemblies a poor experience. I recommended moving all .NET library assemblies (which includes Microsoft.Extensions) and their dependencies to into SharedAssemblies so we don't need to wait for a runtime failure.

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
> The current approach is that only the required assemblies and their dependencies have been added to SharedAssemblies, but that makes finding and fixing any missing assemblies a poor experience. I recommended moving all .NET library assemblies (which includes Microsoft.Extensions) and their dependencies to into SharedAssemblies so we don't need to wait for a runtime failure.

Without aligning the used assemblies in components that can be loaded into ServiceHub I expect the issue to persist, see tarekgh's comment:

> The core issue seems to be that we’re loading mixed versions of Microsoft.Extensions libraries within the same process. I believe the proper solution is to align all these libraries to the same version to avoid conflicts and ensure compatibility.

`Microsoft.WebTools.AspireServer` would still be referencing 8.0 assemblies.

nodes.author: eerhardt
LittleLittleCloud
nodes.body: The fix is in VS main branch now.

nodes.author: ikkentim
nodes.body:
This problem has not yet been resolved in Visual Studio 2022 17.14.11, which was released yesterday.

@LittleLittleCloud should it have been fixed with this update?

nodes.author: LittleLittleCloud
nodes.body: @ikkentim No, the fix is not backported in 17.14.11 yet. It will be available in the next VS release

author: willdean
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

TL;DR:   `WaitForCompletion` does not work when using `dotnet watch` or `aspire run --watch`

We are playing with Aspirifying a .NET 8 Blazor (server) app which uses EF Core with Postgresql.  We're using Aspire 9.3 and generally use the 8.0 SDK but have also tested with the 9.0 SDK before opening this issue.

* Following the guidelines we created a separate 'Migrations' project to run the EF migrations (and seeding) at startup.
* In order to make sure the migrations complete before the app tries to start, we had to add `WaitForCompletion` to the app service.    This works OK when using `aspire run`
* Because this is Blazor server app, we need to use `dotnet watch` (or `aspire run --watch`) for any kind of realistic development loop performance.   Unfortunately when running AppHost under either of those CLI-based watch commands, the Migrations service does not actually complete.   This means that the web app never starts, because of its `WaitForCompletion`
* Manually clicking 'stop' on the  Migrations service in the dashboard does release the web app to start.

I have not tried any kind of IDE-based hot-reload.

There was a previous mention of this here, but it was an addition to an issue which is now closed: https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/6695#issuecomment-2510297236

I doubt "Blazor + EF Migrations" really qualifies as a corner-case so I am probably missing something here, but if I'm not, could we we have one of these:

* Some way to manually mark a service as not-for-hot-reload (clearly it's just useless busywork on a one-shot app anyway)
* Aspire could detect the `WaitForCompletion` and mark the relevant service as not-for-hot-reload
* The `WaitForCompletion` logic could understand the 'watch' quirks a little better and work around them

I am currently running on a Mac but can test on Windows if that might be relevant.

### Expected Behavior

I expect that using watch/hot reload should be compatible with using `WaitForCompletion`

### Steps To Reproduce

Minimal repro: 

https://github.com/willdean/aspire-watch-start-issue

nodes.author: WillEhrendreich
nodes.body:
Is there any workaround for this other than hitting the Stop button every time? 

Ideally, I'd love for the Aspire app to be running normally, but let another sub project be watched, so that the apphost doesn't have to be rebuilt every time, but any changes I make to the real business logic or test code gets to be refreshed and re-run. 

Good luck on this, @tmat. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1887dc45-f7a7-4b93-b37f-81edb25b408c)

nodes.author: willdean
nodes.body:
> Is there any workaround for this other than hitting the Stop button every time?

I stumbled across [this](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/docs/specs/IDE-execution.md) today, which implies that it sbould be possible for Aspire to start apps in ether "IDE" mode (which includes dotnet watch) or in normal (i.e. "just run it") mode.     I don't know if this document is still relevant or this functionality is exposed, but if it was then it seems like a good solution to this problem would be to have a way to mark applications which are expected to run to completion as avoiding the "IDE mode" altogether.   There's simply no point hooking-up the hot-reload mechanism to an app which is going to have finished and exited within a few seconds.

Edit: Having looked at `DcpExecutor.cs`, I don't think this is currently possible - roughly speaking, all projects are started in "IDE" mode and only plain executables in "Process" mode.

author: jguadagno
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Working with a `Program.cs` that has a try/catch block in it where the `builder` object is built, the current Aspire templates place the `builder.AddServiceDefaults()` and the `builder.MapDefaultEndpoints()` outside the try/catch block causing the application to no longer compile.

### Expected Behavior

I would expect that the Aspire template detect the `builder` is being created inside a try/catch block and implement the required Aspire methods in the same block.

### Steps To Reproduce

My public repo of [contacts-noauth](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth) is the starter point for this bug.  Using Visual Studio, add .NET Aspire Orchestration to the *Contacts.Api* project. It will work and create the *AppHost* and *ServiceDefaults* project, however, the project *Contacts.Api* will no longer compile.

If you look at [Program.cs](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth/blob/main/src/Contacts.Api/Program.cs) you will notice there is a try block that starts on line [18](https://github.com/jguadagno/contacts-noauth/blob/b91f0ecb201f4f9a52e9b504d5dc36b43617173b/src/Contacts.Api/Program.cs#L18). The builder is created on line 20.  However, when running the Aspire .NET Orchestration adds the following lines

```csharp
builder.AddServiceDefaults();

builder.MapDefaultEndpoints();
```

to lines 49 and 51, outside the try/catch block where the `builder` object is not available.

_No response_

author: dozer75
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Using the stop button on a project in Aspire Dashboard does not shut down the project gracefully, causing any shutdown operations to be skipped which causes issues for services that does this. E.g., I am communicating in my service with a 3rd party service which requires a cleanup process when not using them anymore. 

I have tried to find what exactly you do, but it stopped finding the cause when I hit some patch operations against K8s (but this isn't executed in K8s, so I lost the tracking).

The projects is also not shut down gracefully when I shut down the app host gracefully either.

### Expected Behavior

Stopping the project in any way should trigger a graceful shutdown (similar to CTRL+C) so that the process can perform cleanup logic during shutdown.

### Steps To Reproduce

- Create a ASP.NET Aspire Starter App project
- After the `var app = builder.Build();` statement in `ApiService/program.cs`  add the following:
```
app.Lifetime.ApplicationStopping.Register(() =>
{
    app.Logger.LogInformation("Application stopping. Performing graceful shutdown tasks...");
});
```
- Set a breakpoint in the action body
- Run the AppHost project
- After everything has started either:
  - stop the `apiservice` project
  - press `CTRL+C` in the AppHost console

Result: The stopping action is not called

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
A couple questions; what version of Aspire.Hosting is your app host referencing and are you running your app host project from the command line or from an IDE? 

We added support for sending a signal when shutting down child services on Windows in Aspire 9.3, but that's only guaranteed to work from the command line. If you're Aspire from an IDE that has Aspire debugging support, the IDE itself is running and terminating the individual project processes to allow for attaching a debugger. At least with VS and VSCode, the debugger doesn't do a graceful shutdown when stopping a process, which means the child process will go away without a chance to do graceful shutdown.

nodes.author: dozer75
nodes.body:
I am running 9.3.0 of Aspire and it is via debugging in Visual Studio. 

I am starting it from Visual Studio for now, but I don't stop the project from Visual Studio. It is (as I mentioned) either from the Aspire Web UI or by stopping the Aspire service in the shell that runs it.

Why this is handled differently based on the app host is started? Why not use the termination signal at all time?

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
Because VS is launching the project processes, we also depend on it to stop (and restart) said projects. When you hit stop in the dashboard while running in VS the behavior is the same as stopping a debugging session in the IDE, which unfortunately VS does by immediately terminating the process tree of the debugged process. 

We can’t send a signal ourselves, because being able to send an interrupt signal to a process in Windows requires a [specific set of circumstances](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/generateconsolectrlevent); when run outside of an IDE, we control how executables are run, so we can guarantee the correct system flags are set to let us send an interrupt signal. If we were to send an interrupt to an IDE launched process, depending on how it was run, it might never receive it or the signal may be sent to VS as well. 

For us to provide signaled shutdown behavior when running in VS, we’d need to convince the team that owns VS debugging that it’s a change they should make. If it’s an important feature to you, you may want to see if anyone else has requested it on [Visual Studio Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/) and open a new request if not.

nodes.author: dozer75
nodes.body:
Ok, that's a pity which effectively stops us from using Aspire for development purposes for this project... Not being able to take down the process gracefully (which you can if you run it explicit in the console) from Aspire is stopping us... 

I am a bit curious how this is implemented in Aspire. Can you point me in the right direction in the code to see how both the projects are initiated both during debugging startup and how the start/stop functionality provided in Aspire dashboard is implemented as well?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: The orchestrator communicates with the IDE https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/docs/specs/IDE-execution.md. The code to launch the process under the debugger is in each IDE. When you run without the IDE the orchestrator does this itself (there's no debugger).

nodes.body:

Slightly different scenario for me: I'm running the Community Toolkit .AddSpringApp sample and the Tomcat service continues to hold the port after stopping .NET Aspire host, but seems like a similar cause.~~

body: ### Is there an existing issue for this? - [x] I have searched the existing issues ### Describe the bug ## Issue When starting Aspire in VSCode for debug, If you try to start >1 instance of `AddProject` for the same project but different identifiers, Aspire seems to get confused about the status of any instances after the first. --- On initial run, it will seem to "hang" on status "starting" for a minute, but the process is actually running: Note that Aspire shows "starting" but there are 2 `Web` processes in VSCode on the left, that are up and running. You can also at this point open localhost:7057 in a browser to the supposedly "unstarted" web server and it will load fine. --- After a minute, Aspire will start to report "Started" for the 2nd Web instance, but it shows a PID of `0` And no longer updates the Console output: On the left is the actual console output from VSCode, on the right is Aspire. If I were to click over to the 1st Web instance in Aspire, that one does show the correct PID and Console output. --- If you try to "Stop" the 2nd `Web` instance once it is in this "running with PID 0" state, it will get an error logged to the Console: ``` Executing command 'resource-stop'. Error executing command 'resource-stop'. System.InvalidOperationException: Failed to stop resource 'webfrontend-2-aucbvmwb'. at Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.DcpExecutor.StopResourceAsync(IResourceReference resourceReference, CancellationToken cancellationToken) in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/Dcp/DcpExecutor.cs:line 1669 at Aspire.Hosting.Orchestrator.ApplicationOrchestrator.StopResourceAsync(String resourceName, CancellationToken cancellationToken) in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/Orchestrator/ApplicationOrchestrator.cs:line 451 at Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.CommandsConfigurationExtensions.<>c.<b__0_3>d.MoveNext() in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/ApplicationModel/CommandsConfigurationExtensions.cs:line 59 --- End of stack trace from previous location --- at Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ResourceCommandService.ExecuteCommandCoreAsync(String resourceId, IResource resource, String commandName, CancellationToken cancellationToken) in /_/src/Aspire.Hosting/ApplicationModel/ResourceCommandService.cs:line 125 ``` ## Seems to be VSCode Specific? On a hunch that this was in some way related to trying to track processes as they attach in the VSCode debugger, I tried running Aspire outside VSCode. From the command line, `dotnet run --project aspire-multi-instance-bug.AppHost` runs as-expected. Both `Web` instances start immediately, report correct PIDs, and have Console output. ## Additional Context I am trying to simulate in Aspire the fairly common deployment strategy of having some services deployed per-tenant in a multi-tenant application. For local dev w/ Aspire I'm fine having 2 or 3 hard-coded "tenants" that start up services in Aspire, but it seems I can't reliably run multiple instances of the same project. ### Expected Behavior Aspire should be able to run multiple instances of the same Project, and not lose track of them. ### Steps To Reproduce Reproduction repo: https://github.com/rally25rs/aspire-multi-instance-bug which is just `dotnet new aspire-starter` with a modified AppHost that tries to start 2 instances of the same project on different ports: ``` builder.AddProject("webfrontend-1") .WithExternalHttpEndpoints() .WithEndpoint("http", endpoint => endpoint.Port = 5284) .WithEndpoint("https", endpoint => endpoint.Port = 7056) .WithHttpHealthCheck("/health") .WithReference(apiService) .WaitFor(apiService); builder.AddProject("webfrontend-2") .WithExternalHttpEndpoints() .WithEndpoint("http", endpoint => endpoint.Port = 5285) .WithEndpoint("https", endpoint => endpoint.Port = 7057) .WithHttpHealthCheck("/health") .WithReference(apiService) .WaitFor(apiService); ``` Clone the above repo and run aspire in debug from VSCode (press F5). ### Exceptions (if any) _No response_ ### .NET Version info .NET SDK: Version: 9.0.301 Commit: a596cd22e2 Workload version: 9.0.300-manifests.9bcbba73 MSBuild version: 17.14.5+edd3bbf37 Runtime Environment: OS Name: Mac OS X OS Version: 15.5 OS Platform: Darwin RID: osx-arm64 Base Path: /usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/9.0.301/ .NET workloads installed: There are no installed workloads to display. Configured to use loose manifests when installing new manifests. title: [9.4.0] Aspire dashboard shows incorrect status and console if >1 of same Project is run

author: LittleLittleCloud
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

IDE here refers to VS/VSCode

Currently, when restarting from aspire dashboard, IDE would not rebuild the underlying project, it just restart from the most recent successful build.

This causes bug if user had applied good edit changes from hotreload before they restarting from aspire dashboard, in best cases they lost all hotreload changes,   and most likely they would get a badimage error the next time they tried to apply a change after restarting.



### Describe the solution you'd like

To address this issue, IDE should also build the projects when they receives restart signal from DCP, this ensure the most recent change has been compiled into dll for the new process.

## Deal with build latency
The build might be time consuming, therefore it might be necessary to make the build process DCP/aspire dashboard aware. see #9321

## Deal with build error
When IDE encounters a build error, it can send a terminate signal to DCP so DCP knows the restarting process is completed (with error).

### Additional context

_No response_
